duck: Gal - The gal, sometimes called galileo, is a unit of acceleration used extensively in the science of gravimetry.
Foot per second squared - The foot per second squared is a unit of acceleration.
acceleration definition: the act or process of accelerating.
Equations of motion - In mathematical physics, equations of motion are equations that describe the behaviour of a physical system in terms of its motion as a function of time.
Angular acceleration - Angular acceleration is the rate of change of angular velocity.
0 to 60 mph (0 to 100 km/h)
Four-vector: making the connection between space and time explicit
In physics, acceleration is the rate at which the velocity of a body changes with time.

wiki.text:
{{Infobox physical quantity |bgcolour={default} |image= |caption= A falling
ball, in the absence of air resistance, accelerates, i.e. it falls faster and
faster. |unit = m / s<sup>2</sup> |symbols = a }}


In physics, 'acceleration' is the rate at which the velocity of a body changes
with time.<ref></ref> In general, velocity and acceleration are vector
quantities, with magnitude and direction,<ref></ref><ref></ref> though in many
cases only magnitude is considered (sometimes with negative values for
deceleration, treating it as a one dimensional vector). As described by Newton's
Second Law, acceleration is caused by a net force; the force, as a vector, is
equal to the product of the mass of the object being accelerated (scalar) and
the acceleration (vector). The SI unit of acceleration is the meter per second
squared (m/s<sup>2</sup>).

For example, an object such as a car that starts from standstill, then travels
in a straight line at increasing speed, is accelerating in the direction of
travel. If the car changes direction at constant speedometer reading, there is
strictly speaking an acceleration although it is often not so described;
passengers in the car will experience a force pushing them back into their seats
in linear acceleration, and a sideways force on changing direction. If the speed
of the car decreases, it is usual and meaningful to speak of 'deceleration';
mathematically it is acceleration in the opposite direction to that of motion.
wiki.title: acceleration
